text:
Arisara Therdthianwong
I am a Master’s student in Business, specializing Data analytics at Monash University. I previously worked as a Supply Chain Officer in Thailand for three years, where I managed inventory, improved warehouse efficiency, and support procurement with suppliers. Currently, I am developing mu skills in communicating data efficiently, through blog building. My first blog post explores the burden of Healthcare-associated infections in Germany. I am an enthusiastic leaner with passion to pursue new challenges in life. I enjoy collaborating in teams with great vibes and bring a foundation in programming to support problem-solving and data analysis.

title: Critical hospital burden: Healthcare-Associated Infections in Germany
text:
Everybody goes to hospital to receive a cure. What if you went there for treatment but ended up with another infection. This is not a rare occurrence since 1 of every 25 patients in Germany were affected. These healthcare-associated infections (HAIs) are a silent crisis that strikes tens of thousands of people every year. In 2011, HAIs resulted in approximately 487,000 cases and claimed over 16,000 lives (Zacher, 2019). To be exactly, the burden of HAIs causes more death than from influenza, Salmonella, Hepatitis B, and Measles combined. Despite Germany’s superb hospitals, the highest number of hospital beds and hospitalization rates exposed Germany to risk.
What’s even more shocking? Research found that many of these infections can be prevented with basic changes in hygiene and hospital procedures.
Understanding where these infections occur and which types are most dangerous is crucial for developing effective prevention strategies.

title: Critical hospital burden: Healthcare-Associated Infections in Germany
text:
The Data

Where the data come from?
This analysis uses data from 2011 European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) Point Prevalence Survey with BHAI method
We examined two datasets for Germany:

Representative sample: 46 hospitals with 9,626 patients
Convenience sample: 132 hospitals with 41,539 patients



What was tracked?
BIG 5 types of HAIs

Clostridioides difficile (CDI)
Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP)
Bloodstream infections (BSI)
Urinary tract infections (UTI)
Surgical site infections (SSI)



What was measured?

Total number of cases
Deaths linked to infection
Years lost to disability or life (YLDs, YLLs, and summed up as DALYs)
